docs.title: Welcome to Daisy
docs.text:
Daisy is a mechanistic simulation of agricultural fields developed by the Agrohydrology group at the University of Copenhagen.

Daisy keeps track of water, nitrogen, carbon, and pesticides in the bioactive zone near the soil surface (roughly top of canopy to the bottom of the (historic) root zone).

docs.title: What can Daisy help you with?
docs.text:
• Optimize crop yields - Model different management strategies to maximize productivity
  • Minimize nutrient losses - Reduce environmental impact while maintaining yields
  • Avoid pesticide pollution - Understand pesticide fate and transport in agricultural systems
  • And much more! - Comprehensive agricultural system modeling

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Choose your platform to begin using Daisy:

  • MacOS

    Get started with Daisy on MacOS systems

    MacOS Setup

  • Windows

    Get started with Daisy on Windows systems

    Windows Setup

docs.title: Editor Setup
docs.text:
Enhance your Daisy experience with a properly configured editor:

  • Visual Studio Code - Modern, feature-rich editor with syntax highlighting
  • TextPad - Lightweight Windows editor with Daisy integration

docs.title: Additional Resources
docs.text:
• Python Setup - Configure Python for use with Daisy
  • Official Daisy Website - More information about the Daisy project
  • GitHub Repository - Source code and development

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
If you encounter issues or have questions:

  1. Check the relevant setup guide for your platform
  2. Visit our GitHub Issues page
  3. Consult the official Daisy website for additional resources

docs.title: Python Setup for Daisy
docs.text:
This guide covers setting up Python to work with Daisy for data analysis and visualization.

Python Version Requirement

Daisy requires Python 3.13 for optimal compatibility. Other versions may not work correctly.

docs.title: Platform-Specific Setup
docs.text: MacOSWindowsLinux

docs.title: Install Python 3.13
docs.text:
1. Download Python 3.13.2 from the official Python website
  2. Launch the installer package
  3. Follow the installation instructions

Important

Do not use Homebrew or other package managers to install Python for Daisy. Use the official python.org installer.

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
python3 --version
# Should output: Python 3.13.2

docs.title: Install Python 3.13
docs.text:
1. Download Python 3.13.2 from python.org
  2. Run the installer
  3. Important: Check "Add Python to PATH" during installation
  4. Follow the installation wizard

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
python --version
# Should output: Python 3.13.2

docs.title: Install Python 3.13
docs.text:
Most Linux distributions may not have Python 3.13 in their default repositories yet. You may need to:

  1. Use pyenv (recommended): 

    curl https://pyenv.run | bash
pyenv install 3.13.2
pyenv global 3.13.2

  2. Or compile from source following the official guide

docs.title: Installing Analysis Packages
docs.text: Once Python is installed, you can install packages for analyzing Daisy output files.

docs.title: For R Users: daisyrVis
docs.text:
If you prefer R for data analysis:

# Install from R console
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("daisy-model/daisyrVis")

docs.title: For Python Users: daispy-vis
docs.text:
If you prefer Python for data analysis:

# Install the Daisy Python visualization package
pip install git+https://github.com/daisy-model/daisypy-vis

docs.title: Basic Data Analysis Setup
docs.text:
For general data analysis of Daisy output files:

# Install common data analysis packages
pip install pandas matplotlib numpy seaborn jupyter

docs.title: Working with Daisy Output Files
docs.text: Daisy generates .dlf files (Daisy Log Format) which are tab-separated files with custom headers.

docs.title: Reading DLF Files in Python
docs.text:
import pandas as pd

# Read a Daisy output file
df = pd.read_csv('field_water.dlf', sep='\t', skiprows=1)
print(df.head())

docs.title: Basic Visualization Example
docs.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Read and plot water content over time
df = pd.read_csv('field_water.dlf', sep='\t', skiprows=1)
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(df['Date'], df['Water_Content'])
plt.title('Soil Water Content Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Water Content')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

docs.title: Jupyter Notebook Setup
docs.text:
For interactive analysis, set up Jupyter notebooks:

# Install Jupyter
pip install jupyter

# Start Jupyter notebook server
jupyter notebook

This will open a web interface where you can create notebooks for analyzing your Daisy simulations.

docs.title: Virtual Environments (Recommended)
docs.text:
To avoid conflicts with other Python projects, use virtual environments:

WindowsMacOS/Linux 
# Create virtual environment
python -m venv daisy-env

# Activate it
daisy-env\Scripts\activate

# Install packages
pip install pandas matplotlib jupyter

# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv daisy-env

# Activate it
source daisy-env/bin/activate

# Install packages
pip install pandas matplotlib jupyter

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Python not found after installation

Windows: Make sure you checked "Add Python to PATH" during installation

MacOS: You may need to use python3 instead of python

All platforms: Restart your terminal/command prompt after installation

pip install fails with permission errors

Solutions:

  • Use virtual environments (recommended)
  • Add --user flag: pip install --user package-name
  • On Windows: Run command prompt as Administrator
Wrong Python version being used

Check your PATH: Multiple Python installations can conflict

# Check which Python is being used
which python3  # MacOS/Linux
where python   # Windows
Package import errors

Verify installation: 

import sys
print(sys.version)  # Check Python version
print(sys.path)     # Check package search paths

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
For Python-specific issues:

  1. Check the Python documentation
  2. Visit Stack Overflow for common problems
  3. For Daisy-specific Python issues, check our GitHub Issues

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
With Python set up, you can:

  1. Analyze simulation results using pandas and matplotlib
  2. Create visualizations of your Daisy model outputs
  3. Automate analysis workflows with Python scripts
  4. Use Jupyter notebooks for interactive exploration
  5. Integrate with other tools in the Python ecosystem

docs.title: Setup TextPad for Daisy
docs.text:
TextPad is a lightweight, Windows-native text editor that provides excellent support for Daisy development. This guide will help you configure TextPad for the best Daisy experience.

Windows Only

TextPad is a Windows-only editor. For cross-platform alternatives, consider Visual Studio Code.

docs.title: Why TextPad for Daisy?
docs.text:
TextPad offers several advantages for Daisy development:

  • Parenthesis pair matching - Essential for Lisp-like syntax
  • Syntax highlighting - Color-coded models, components, and parentheses
  • Integrated execution - Run Daisy directly from the editor
  • Lightweight - Fast startup and low resource usage
  • Windows integration - Native Windows look and feel

docs.title: Installation Process
docs.text:
The setup involves three main steps:

  1. Install TextPad and support files
  2. Create a Daisy document class
  3. Add Daisy to the Tools menu

docs.title: Install TextPad
docs.text:
1. Download TextPad from textpad.com
  2. Install TextPad on your computer
  3. Remember the installation directory (usually C:\Program Files\TextPad)

docs.title: Download Daisy Support Files
docs.text:
1. Download the TextPad Daisy support files
  2. Extract the zip file - you should get these files:
  3. Dai.syn - Syntax highlighting definition
  4. Daisy.tcl - Tool configuration
  5. Daisy2.tcl - Alternative tool configuration
  6. Daisy3.tcl - Another tool configuration
  7. Copy all files to the "Samples" directory under your TextPad installation
  8. Usually: C:\Program Files\TextPad\Samples\

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Daisy Document Class
docs.text:
This step enables syntax highlighting for .dai files.

  1. Start TextPad
  2. Open the Configure menu
  3. Select "New Document Class..."
  4. Configure the class:
  5. Class name: Daisy
  6. Click "Next"
  7. Set file pattern:
  8. Class members: *.dai
  9. Click "Next"
  10. Enable syntax highlighting:
  11. Check "Enable syntax highlighting"
  12. Syntax definition file: Select Dai.syn from dropdown
  13. Click "Next"
  14. Click "Apply"
  15. Exit TextPad to make changes take effect

Test Syntax Highlighting

When you reopen TextPad and load a .dai file, you should see syntax highlighting with pretty colors!

docs.title: Step 3: Add Daisy to the Tools Menu
docs.text: This step allows you to run Daisy simulations directly from TextPad.

docs.title: Configure the Tool
docs.text:
1. Start TextPad
  2. Open the Configure menu
  3. Select "Preferences..."
  4. Click on "Tools" (the name, not the checkbox)
  5. Add Daisy executable:
  6. Click "Add" → Choose "Program..."
  7. Navigate to and select daisy.exe
    • Usually in: C:\Program Files\daisy 7.1.0\bin\daisy.exe
  8. Click "Apply"

docs.title: Configure Error Navigation
docs.text:
1. Expand the Tools section (click the checkbox next to "Tools")
  2. Select "Daisy" from the list
  3. Configure error parsing:
  4. Regular expression: ([^:\\]+):(\d+):(\d+)
  5. File dropdown: Choose 1
  6. Line dropdown: Choose 2
  7. Column dropdown: Choose 3
  8. Click "Apply"
  9. Exit TextPad to save changes

Error Navigation

With this configuration, you can double-click on error messages in the output to jump directly to the problematic line in your code!

docs.title: Running Simulations
docs.text:
1. Open a .dai file in TextPad
  2. Run the simulation:
  3. Menu: Tools → External Tools → Daisy
  4. Or use keyboard shortcut (if configured)
  5. View output in the separate output window
  6. Navigate to errors by double-clicking error messages

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
You can assign keyboard shortcuts to run Daisy:

  1. Open Configure → Preferences
  2. Go to Keyboard
  3. Find "Daisy" in the Commands list
  4. Assign a shortcut (e.g., F5 or Ctrl+R)

docs.title: Working with Multiple Files
docs.text:
TextPad supports:

  • Multiple tabs - Work on several .dai files simultaneously
  • Project management - Group related files together
  • Find in files - Search across multiple Daisy files

docs.title: Custom Syntax Highlighting
docs.text:
You can modify Dai.syn to customize syntax highlighting:

  1. Open C:\Program Files\TextPad\Samples\Dai.syn
  2. Edit color schemes and keyword definitions
  3. Save and restart TextPad

docs.title: Multiple Daisy Versions
docs.text:
To support multiple Daisy installations:

  1. Add each version as a separate tool in Preferences
  2. Give them distinct names (e.g., "Daisy 7.0.7", "Daisy 7.1.0")
  3. Assign different shortcuts to each version

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Syntax highlighting not working

Check:

  • Dai.syn file is in the Samples directory
  • Document class is properly configured
  • File extension is .dai
  • TextPad was restarted after configuration
Daisy tool not found

Verify:

  • Path to daisy.exe is correct
  • Daisy is properly installed
  • You have permissions to execute daisy.exe
Error navigation not working

Ensure:

  • Regular expression is exactly: ([^:\\]+):(\d+):(\d+)
  • Dropdown selections are: File=1, Line=2, Column=3
  • Error messages contain file:line:column format
Output window doesn't appear

Try:

  • Check Windows → Output to show the output window
  • Verify Daisy is producing output
  • Check that the working directory is correct

docs.title: File Association Issues
docs.text:
If Windows doesn't recognize .dai files:

  1. Right-click a .dai file
  2. Choose "Open with" → "Choose another app"
  3. Select TextPad
  4. Check "Always use this app"

docs.title: Comparison with Other Editors
docs.text: Feature TextPad VSCode Platform Windows only Cross-platform Resource usage Very light Moderate Setup complexity Moderate Moderate Syntax highlighting Good Excellent Error navigation Good Excellent Extensibility Limited Extensive Learning curve Easy Moderate

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
With TextPad configured:

  1. Open sample Daisy files to test syntax highlighting
  2. Try running a simulation using the Tools menu
  3. Experiment with error navigation by introducing syntax errors
  4. Customize shortcuts and preferences to your liking
  5. Explore TextPad's other features like macros and clips

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
For TextPad-specific issues:

  1. Check the TextPad documentation
  2. Visit the TextPad support forums
  3. For Daisy-specific TextPad issues, check our GitHub Issues

docs.title: Setup Visual Studio Code for Daisy
docs.text:
Visual Studio Code (VSCode) is a modern, feature-rich editor that provides excellent support for Daisy development with syntax highlighting, autocompletion, and integrated execution.

Why VSCode?

VSCode offers the best development experience for Daisy with features like:

  • Syntax highlighting for .dai files
  • Integrated terminal for running simulations
  • Error highlighting and navigation
  • Extensible with plugins
  • Cross-platform support

docs.title: Before You Begin
docs.text: If you already have VSCode installed, ensure that old Daisy-related configurations are removed from your settings.json file to avoid conflicts.

docs.title: Install VSCode
docs.text:
1. Download VSCode from code.visualstudio.com
  2. Install following the platform-specific instructions
  3. Launch VSCode

docs.title: Enable Syntax Highlighting
docs.text: Daisy uses a Lisp-like syntax, so we'll configure VSCode to treat .dai files as Lisp files.

docs.title: Install a Lisp Extension
docs.text:
1. Open the Extensions view (Ctrl+Shift+X)
  2. Search for "Lisp" in the marketplace
  3. Choose one of these options:
Basic HighlightingAdvanced Features

Install Lisp by mattn

  • Provides syntax highlighting only
  • Lightweight and fast
  • Good for basic editing

Install Common Lisp by qingpeng

  • Syntax highlighting + autocompletion
  • More features but slightly heavier
  • Better for extensive development

docs.title: Configure File Association
docs.text:
1. Open a .dai file in VSCode
  2. Open Command Palette (F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P)
  3. Type and select "Change Language Mode"
  4. Select "Configure File Association for '.dai'..."
  5. Type "lisp" and select your installed Lisp extension

docs.title: Setup VSCode to Run Daisy
docs.text:
There are two complementary approaches for running Daisy from VSCode:

  1. Launch Configuration - Run with F5 (single Daisy version)
  2. Tasks + Keybindings - Custom shortcuts (multiple Daisy versions)

docs.title: Method 1: Launch Configuration (F5 to Run)
docs.text: This method is ideal if you have one Daisy installation and want simple F5 execution.

docs.title: Set Default Terminal (Windows Only)
docs.text:
Windows Users

For Daisy's spawn program to work correctly, you must use Command Prompt (cmd.exe), not PowerShell.

  1. Open Command Palette (F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P)
  2. Type and select "Terminal: Select Default Profile"
  3. Choose "Command Prompt"

docs.title: Configure the Launch Settings
docs.text:
1. Open Command Palette (F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P)
  2. Type and select "Preferences: Open User Settings (JSON)"
  3. Add this configuration under the "launch" section:
WindowsMacOS 
{
    // ... other settings ...
    "launch": {
        "configurations": [
            {
                "name": "Run Daisy",
                "request": "launch",
                "type": "node-terminal",
                "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
                "command": "\"C:/Program Files/daisy 7.1.0/bin/daisy.exe\" \"${file}\""
            }
        ]
    }
    // ... other settings ...
}

{
    // ... other settings ...
    "launch": {
        "configurations": [
            {
                "name": "Run Daisy",
                "request": "launch", 
                "type": "node-terminal",
                "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
                "command": "\"/Applications/Daisy/bin/daisy\" \"${file}\""
            }
        ]
    }
    // ... other settings ...
}

Path Adjustment

Replace the path in the command field with your actual Daisy installation path.

docs.title: Method 2: Tasks + Keybindings (Multiple Versions)
docs.text: This method allows you to switch between multiple Daisy versions using custom keyboard shortcuts.

docs.title: Configure Tasks
docs.text:
1. Open Command Palette (F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P)
  2. Type and select "Tasks: Configure Task"
  3. Select "Create tasks.json file from template"
  4. Choose "Others"
  5. Replace the content with:
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "daisy-7.1.0",
            "type": "process",
            "command": "C:/Program Files/daisy 7.1.0/bin/daisy.exe",
            "args": ["${file}"],
            "group": "build",
            "presentation": {
                "echo": true,
                "reveal": "always",
                "focus": false,
                "panel": "new"
            }
        }
    ]
}

docs.title: Configure Keybindings
docs.text:
1. Open Command Palette (F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P)
  2. Type and select "Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts (JSON)"
  3. Add this keybinding:
[
    {
        "key": "ctrl+r 1",
        "command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
        "args": "daisy-7.1.0"
    }
]

docs.title: Test the Setup
docs.text:
1. Open a .dai file
  2. Press and release Ctrl+R, then press 1
  3. Daisy should run in the integrated terminal

docs.title: Multiple Daisy Versions
docs.text:
To support multiple Daisy installations, add more tasks and keybindings:

tasks.jsonkeybindings.json 
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "daisy-7.0.7",
            "type": "process",
            "command": "C:/Program Files/daisy 7.0.7/bin/daisy.exe",
            "args": ["${file}"]
        },
        {
            "label": "daisy-7.1.0", 
            "type": "process",
            "command": "C:/Program Files/daisy 7.1.0/bin/daisy.exe",
            "args": ["${file}"]
        }
    ]
}

[
    {
        "key": "ctrl+r 1",
        "command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
        "args": "daisy-7.0.7"
    },
    {
        "key": "ctrl+r 2", 
        "command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
        "args": "daisy-7.1.0"
    }
]

docs.title: settings.json
docs.text:
{
    "files.associations": {
        "*.dai": "commonlisp"
    },
    "launch": {
        "configurations": [
            {
                "name": "Run Daisy",
                "request": "launch",
                "type": "node-terminal",
                "command": "\"C:/Program Files/daisy 7.1.0/bin/daisy.exe\" \"${file}\"",
                "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}"
            }
        ]
    },
    "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.windows": "Command Prompt"
}

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Syntax highlighting not working

Solutions:

  • Verify the Lisp extension is installed and enabled
  • Check that .dai files are associated with the Lisp language mode
  • Restart VSCode after making changes
F5 doesn't run Daisy

Check:

  • Launch configuration is properly added to settings.json
  • File paths in the configuration are correct
  • On Windows, ensure Command Prompt is the default terminal
Task keybindings not working

Verify:

  • tasks.json exists in .vscode folder in your workspace
  • keybindings.json has the correct task names
  • Try the Command Palette: "Tasks: Run Task" to test manually
Permission denied errors

Solutions:

  • Run VSCode as Administrator (Windows)
  • Check file permissions on the Daisy executable
  • Ensure the working directory is writable

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
For VSCode-specific issues:

  1. Check the VSCode documentation
  2. Visit the VSCode GitHub repository
  3. For Daisy-specific VSCode issues, check our GitHub Issues

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
With VSCode configured:

  1. Open a Daisy project folder in VSCode
  2. Try running a sample file using F5 or your custom keybindings
  3. Explore the integrated terminal for command-line operations
  4. Install additional extensions like Git integration or file explorers
  5. Customize your workspace with VSCode's extensive settings

docs.title: Getting Started on MacOS
docs.text: This guide will help you install and set up Daisy on macOS systems.

docs.title: Download and Install Daisy
docs.text:
1. Download the latest release of Daisy from GitHub Releases
  2. Run the installer package
  3. Follow the installation prompts

Installation Directory

In the following instructions, we refer to <daisy-dir>. This is the folder where you install Daisy, which is most likely /Applications/Daisy.

docs.title: Setup Python on MacOS
docs.text:
Python Requirement

To use Python with Daisy on macOS, it is necessary to install Python manually. Daisy will only work with Python 3.13.

docs.title: Install Python 3.13
docs.text:
1. Download Python 3.13.2 from the official Python website
  2. Launch the installer package
  3. Follow the installation instructions

docs.title: Setting up Your Development Environment
docs.text: While you can run Daisy from the command line, we recommend using a text editor for a better experience.

docs.title: Recommended Editor: TextMate
docs.text:
We recommend using TextMate as your editor. The Daisy distribution includes a support bundle for TextMate:

  • Bundle Location: <daisy-dir>/TextMate/Daisy.tmbundle
  • Features: Syntax highlighting, code completion, and integrated execution

For detailed TextMate setup instructions, see our editor setup guides.

docs.title: Running Your First Daisy Program
docs.text: Daisy includes several sample programs to help you get started.

docs.title: Sample Files Location
docs.text: Sample programs are located in: <daisy-dir>/sample/

docs.title: Step-by-Step Tutorial
docs.text:
1. Create a workspace folder 

    mkdir ~/Desktop/daisy

  2. Copy the test file 

    cp "<daisy-dir>/sample/test.dai" ~/Desktop/daisy/

  3. Open the file in your editor

  4. Navigate to ~/Desktop/daisy/

  5. Open test.dai in your preferred editor

  6. Run the simulation

  7. Execute the test.dai file using your editor or command line
  8. The simulation will process and generate output files

docs.title: Expected Output Files
docs.text:
After running the simulation, you should see these files in your daisy folder:

File Description checkpoint-1987-8-7+6.dai Simulation state for hot-starting daisy.log Simulation log file field_nitrogen.dlf Field nitrogen data field_water.dlf Field water data harvest.dlf Harvest data sbarley.dlf Spring barley data soil_nitrogen.dlf Soil nitrogen data soil_water.dlf Soil water data

docs.title: Understanding Output Files
docs.text:
The .dlf files are tab-separated data files with custom headers that can be:

  • Opened in spreadsheet applications (Excel, Numbers, etc.)
  • Analyzed with programming languages (R, Python, etc.)

docs.title: Recommended Analysis Tools
docs.text:
R UsersPython Users

Use RStudio with the daisyrVis package: 

install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("daisy-model/daisyrVis")

Use Python with the daispy-vis package: 

pip install git+https://github.com/daisy-model/daisypy-vis

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have Daisy running:

  1. Configure an Editor - Set up Visual Studio Code for enhanced development
  2. Explore More Samples - Try other example files in the sample directory
  3. Learn the Language - Study the .dai file syntax and structure
  4. Read Documentation - Visit daisy.ku.dk for detailed model documentation

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Python not found error

Make sure you've installed Python 3.13 from python.org, not from Homebrew or other sources.

Permission denied when running Daisy

Check that the Daisy executable has proper permissions: 

chmod +x "<daisy-dir>/bin/daisy"

Sample files not found

Verify your Daisy installation is complete and the sample directory exists at <daisy-dir>/sample/.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter other issues:

  1. Check our GitHub Issues
  2. Visit the official Daisy website
  3. Review the Python setup guide for Python-specific issues

docs.title: Getting Started Overview
docs.text: This section will help you get Daisy up and running on your system. Choose the guide that matches your operating system:

docs.title: MacOS
docs.text: If you're using a Mac, follow our MacOS setup guide which covers: - Downloading and installing Daisy - Setting up Python 3.13 - Configuring your development environment - Running your first simulation

docs.title: Windows
docs.text: If you're using Windows, follow our Windows setup guide which covers: - Choosing between installer and zip distribution - Setting up your development environment - Running your first simulation

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of these guides, you'll be able to:

  1. Install Daisy on your system
  2. Set up Python (if needed for your platform)
  3. Configure an editor for writing Daisy files
  4. Run your first simulation using the included sample files
  5. Understand the output files generated by Daisy

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After completing the initial setup:

  1. Configure an Editor - Set up Visual Studio Code or TextPad for a better development experience
  2. Explore Sample Files - Learn from the example simulations included with Daisy
  3. Read the Documentation - Visit the official Daisy website for detailed model documentation

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• Operating System: Windows 10+, macOS 10.14+, or Linux
  • Memory: 4 GB RAM
  • Storage: 500 MB free space
  • Python: 3.13 (required for Python integration)

docs.title: Recommended
docs.text:
• Memory: 8 GB RAM or more
  • Storage: 2 GB free space for samples and output files
  • Editor: Visual Studio Code or TextPad for enhanced editing experience

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you run into issues during setup:

  1. Check the troubleshooting sections in the platform-specific guides
  2. Visit our GitHub Issues page
  3. Consult the official documentation

docs.title: Getting Started on Windows
docs.text: This guide will help you install and set up Daisy on Windows systems.

docs.title: Download Daisy
docs.text:
Download the latest release from GitHub Releases.

We provide two distribution options:

Windows Installer (Recommended)Zip Archive
  • File: daisy-setup.exe (or similar)
  • Pros: Automatic installation, Start menu integration
  • Cons: Requires administrator privileges
  • Installation Path: Usually C:\Program Files\daisy 7.1.0
  • File: daisy-windows.zip (or similar)
  • Pros: No admin rights needed, portable
  • Cons: Manual setup required
  • Installation: Extract to your preferred location

Installation Directory

In the following instructions, we refer to <daisy-dir>. This is the folder where you install Daisy.

  • Installer: Usually C:\Program Files\daisy 7.1.0
  • Zip: Wherever you extracted the files

docs.title: Setting up Your Development Environment
docs.text: While you can run Daisy from the command line, we strongly recommend using a text editor for the best experience.

docs.title: Recommended Editors
docs.text:
Choose one of these editors for optimal Daisy development:

  • Visual Studio Code - Modern, feature-rich editor (recommended)
  • TextPad - Lightweight, Windows-native editor

Both editors can be configured with: - Syntax highlighting for .dai files - Integrated Daisy execution - Error highlighting and navigation

docs.title: Running Your First Daisy Program
docs.text: Daisy includes several sample programs to help you get started.

docs.title: Sample Files Location
docs.text: Sample programs are located in: <daisy-dir>\sample\

docs.title: Step-by-Step Tutorial
docs.text:
1. Create a workspace folder
  2. Right-click on your Desktop
  3. Select "New" → "Folder"

  4. Name it daisy

  5. Copy the test file

  6. Navigate to <daisy-dir>\sample\
  7. Copy test.dai

  8. Paste it into your Desktop daisy folder

  9. Open the file in your editor

  10. Open your configured editor (VSCode or TextPad)

  11. Open the test.dai file from your Desktop daisy folder

  12. Run the simulation

  13. Use your editor's run command (typically F5 or Ctrl+R)
  14. Or run from command line: "<daisy-dir>\bin\daisy.exe" test.dai

docs.title: Expected Output Files
docs.text:
After running the simulation, you should see these files in your daisy folder:

File Description checkpoint-1987-8-7+6.dai Simulation state for hot-starting daisy.log Simulation log file field_nitrogen.dlf Field nitrogen data field_water.dlf Field water data harvest.dlf Harvest data sbarley.dlf Spring barley data soil_nitrogen.dlf Soil nitrogen data soil_water.dlf Soil water data

docs.title: Understanding Output Files
docs.text:
The .dlf files are tab-separated data files with custom headers that can be:

  • Opened in Excel or other spreadsheet applications
  • Analyzed with programming languages (R, Python, etc.)

docs.title: Recommended Analysis Tools
docs.text:
R UsersPython UsersExcel Users

Use RStudio with the daisyrVis package: 

install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("daisy-model/daisyrVis")

Use Python with the daispy-vis package: 

pip install git+https://github.com/daisy-model/daisypy-vis

  1. Open Excel
  2. File → Open → Select a .dlf file
  3. Choose "Delimited" in the Text Import Wizard
  4. Select "Tab" as the delimiter

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have Daisy running:

  1. Configure an Editor - Set up Visual Studio Code or TextPad
  2. Explore More Samples - Try other example files in the sample directory
  3. Learn the Language - Study the .dai file syntax and structure
  4. Read Documentation - Visit daisy.ku.dk for detailed model documentation

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Daisy executable not found

Solution: Verify your installation path and ensure daisy.exe exists in <daisy-dir>\bin\

Permission denied error

Solutions:

  • Run your editor as Administrator
  • Or use the zip distribution instead of the installer
  • Or install to a user directory instead of Program Files
Sample files not found

Solution: Check that your Daisy installation is complete and the sample directory exists at <daisy-dir>\sample\

Output files not generated

Possible causes:

  • Check the daisy.log file for error messages
  • Ensure you have write permissions in the working directory
  • Verify the .dai file syntax is correct

docs.title: Command Line Usage
docs.text:
If you prefer command line execution:

cd /d "C:\path\to\your\daisy\files"
"<daisy-dir>\bin\daisy.exe" test.dai

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter other issues:

  1. Check our GitHub Issues
  2. Visit the official Daisy website
  3. Review the editor setup guides for configuration help
